title: GameStop Stock Is Tumbling After Its Earnings Show Even Used Game Sales Are Slowing
text:
Text size

GameStop stock has dropped more than 15% in after-hours trading after the videogame retailer reported a larger-than-expected loss.

GameStop reported a loss of 32 cents a share, missing forecasts for a loss of 18 cents share, according to FactSet, on sales of $1.29 billion, below estimates for $1.34 billion. The bad news didn’t stop there: same-store sales dropped 12%.

At least GameStop’s management seem to know they have a problem.

“We are committed to acting with a sense of urgency to address the areas of the business that are critical to achieving long-term success and value creation for all our stakeholders,” George Sherman, GameStop’s chief executive officer, said in a news release with the earnings report. “We will set GameStop on the correct strategic path and fully leverage our unique position and brand in the video game industry.”

In July, Barron’s Jack Hough included GameStop in his list of retail stocks that were cheap for a reason. One reason: Worries that digital downloads could hurt GameStop’s used-disc business.

That may be happening. “At first glance, GameStop’s F2Q 2019 results were much worse than consensus expectations and provide further evidence the new management team has a difficult task ahead as it attempts to turn the company around in our opinion,” writes Loop Capital Markets’ Anthony Chukumba. “We were particularly discouraged by the continued weakness in pre-owned and value video game products sales (which dropped by a high-teens percentage despite a YoY gross margin decline) and management’s worse-than-expected F2019 diluted EPS guidance.”

GameStop stock has dropped 15% to $4.31 at 4:37 p.m. in after-hours trading. It gained 6.9% in regular trading hours Tuesday.
